# Open Boria Mine Door

**Difficulty**: :fontawesome-solid-star::fontawesome-solid-star::fontawesome-regular-star::fontawesome-regular-star::fontawesome-regular-star:<br/>
**Direct link**: [minedoor website](src="https://hhc22-novel.kringlecon.com?&challenge=minedoor&id=e4ea87e3-7969-4a49-b110-8882b7e1ff2c")


## Objective

!!! question "Request"
    Open the door to the Boria Mines. Help Alabaster Snowball in the Web Ring to get some hints for this challenge.

??? quote "Hal Tandybuck"
    Oh hi, I'm Hal Tandybuck. And who might you be?<br/>
    I'm hanging out by the door to the mines here because, well, I haven't figured out the locks yet.<br/>
    It actually reminds me of this locked crate I had three years ago...<br/>
    Think you can help me get through?


## Hints

??? hint "Content-Security-Policy"
    Understanding how [Content-Security-Policy](https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Content_Security_Policy_Cheat_Sheet.html) works can help with this challenge.

??? hint "Input Validation"
    Developers use both client- and server-side [input validation](https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Input_Validation_Cheat_Sheet.html) to keep out naughty input.

??? hint "Evab on Discord"
    The locks take input, render some type of image, and process on the back end to unlock. To start, take a good look at the source HTML/JavaScript.

## Solution

The idea is to connect the left and right connections for each pin with a line in the same color. The easiest way to do that is to make it fill the background completely with a single color, at least for the first couple of pins.

Pin1: `@&@&&W&&W&&&&` or a series of `&block;` characters will make a good horizontal connection.

Pin2: `<div style="background: blue; width: 200px; height: 170px;"></div>` which will render a properly-sized div that will connect input and output.

Pin3 has the following CSP set: `<meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; style-src 'self'">`

But it also has a CSP line commented out: `<!-- <meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="default-src 'self'; img-src https://*; child-src 'none';"> -->`

We can submit base64 encoded data for an image of a `#0000ff` rectangle:

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

Alternatively, we can use the first or second lock to first generate a full blue PNG image, copy its link, and then submit `<img src="images/ecf20d49ece04547486482ab37dce0c2d84d00b1.png">` on Pin3 to have the server load it from a local file.

Pin4 has form input sanitation using `onblur="sanitizeInput()"`. This JavaScript function strips specific characters from the input before submitting the form. Use your web browser tools to edit the pin4 HTML form and remove the whole `onblur` parameter.

<div style="background: white; width: 200px; height: 85px;"></div>
<div style="background: blue; width: 200px; height: 85px;"></div>

Pin5 is similar to the base64 solution of pin3 in combination with the input sanitation from pin4, so we use a different image and remove the `onblur` parameter from the form as well.

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">

Pin 6 again has CSP set: `<meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="script-src 'self'; style-src 'self'">` so script and style tags won't work. We we can reuse our base64 image workaround one final time.

<img src="data:image/png;base64,">


!!! done "Answer"
    See the solution above.


## Response

!!! quote "Hal Tandybuck"
    Great! Thanks so much for your help!<br/>
    When you get to the fountain inside, there are some things you should consider.<br/>
    First, it might be helpful to focus on Glamtariel's CAPITALIZED words.<br/>
    If you finish those locks, I might just have another hint for you!<br/>

!!! quote "Hal Tandybuck"
    Wha - what?? You opened all the locks?! Well then...<br/>
    Did you see the nearby terminal with evidence of an XXE attack?<br/>
    Maybe take a close look at that kind of thing.
